excerpts: The memorable ones were the Hawaiian style tuna poke (very unique dish, loved the mix of tuna, seaweed, and fish eggs), Uni (he gave us a good portion of Uni on spoons), fish tacos (the variety of fishes on this taco made this dish so delicious).
hawaiian style tuna poke.author: Beth H.
hawaiian style tuna poke.review:
I came here with a group of four at 830pm. We waited around 30 minutes as it had super limited space, like everything around downtown SF. 

Food: a friend from my group knew the guy behind the bar and he was super nice and let us try a variety of appetizers. The memorable ones were the Hawaiian style tuna poke (very unique dish, loved the mix of tuna, seaweed, and fish eggs), Uni (he gave us a good portion of Uni on spoons), fish tacos (the variety of fishes on this taco made this dish so delicious). I would highly recommend trying out appetizers, the blend of ingredients in these dishes made them so delicious.

Aside from appetizers we also got some rolls. The temptation roll (had a creamy crab taste) and domo roll were yummy. 

Definitely try to come with a group and share a variety of plates as each plate is very unique in its own way. Very different than a normal sushi bar.

excerpts:
We ordered the following:

Hawaiian Style Tuna Poke--pretty good but nothing too special.
hawaiian style tuna poke.author: Jessica T.
hawaiian style tuna poke.review:
Domo is something different than what I normally eat.  My friends and I chose this place because another sushi place was too packed so I didn't read the full details before coming here.  The place was really small and cute.  My friends and I were the first group there for dinner.

We ordered the following:

Hawaiian Style Tuna Poke--pretty good but nothing too special.  They just mixed tuna and wakame and topped it with tako.

Crudos--Salmon & Scallops.  They were both delicious. It's probably my favorite dish ordered.  They are in spoons and it's like drinking a shooter.

Sake Nigiri--nothing too special. It was a lot smaller than I expected but still good.

Rock & Roll--unagi and avocado roll.  The ratio of avocado to unagi was 2:1. I like avocado though so thought the roll was good.

Fire Cracker Balls--These came out very small.  It just tasted like deep fried rice balls topped with their sauces.

Spicy Hulk--tuna inside a cucumber wrap. Good but probably wouldn't order it again.

The owner was very nice to us and constantly checked up on us.  This place can be pricey if you're looking to leave full.  I had to order more food because I was not full and no where near satisfied.

I would recommend this place as a place to try at least once.

excerpts: My friends decided to share an order of the Hawaiian Style Tuna Poke.
hawaiian style tuna poke.author: Tom T.
hawaiian style tuna poke.review:
Domo. The first thing that pops in my head when I hear Domo is Bubzbeauty's puppy, the small brown furry sucker.

Besides the point, my friend wanted to go to Eiji. Sad to say, they decided to take a summer vacation this week and we were in tears, sitting on the curb, wondering how it would have been if we had a taste of the sweet sweet dango.

She had another place already in mind, Domo. Only problem was that it was pretty far from where we were, in terms of walking. Decided to drive there and was seated promptly during prime lunch time. Note, this place isn't the usual chair-and-table restaurant; every seat was a bar seat, and lucky for me and my friend and her boyfriend, we managed to nab three window bar seats.

Since I didn't have unagi in ages, I immediately decided on the Open Face Dragon, Who can say no to the combination of freshwater eel, tempera shrimp AND avocado over rice? My friends decided to share an order of the Hawaiian Style Tuna Poke.

Both options were pretty good; Open Face Dragon was plated with a elegant design that you would probably see in a 5-star place. I was considered that the place was going to give me a straight up bento box with all of these things in its compartments; I am pleased for the fact that Domo decided to elevate something that seems so basic.

My friend did mention that she was concern about taking me here, since she never had tried it and that it was catered more towards the American crowd, not the old-fashion hole-in-the-wall Japanese ryouri that I can get back home in Little Tokyo. Lucky for me, that thought disappeared as soon as she took her first bite of her own food.

A place to get a nice meal, if you don't mind shelling out a few extra dollars.

excerpts:
Here's the run-down of what we divulged in:
Hawaiian Style Tuna Poke - delicious, nice flavors, but not groundbreaking in terms of innovative flavors, yet still worth the price.
Small crudos, spicy tuna and scallop - once again delicious
: tuna tasted fresh, seasoning was good, but I particularly enjoyed the scallop.
hawaiian style tuna poke.author: Emmeline A.
hawaiian style tuna poke.review:
I'm truly a sucker for good music playing in the background, and Domo definitely gets it right.  There's something about the mix of jazz and sushi, and of R&B/hip-hip and sushi that really works. Domo to me is the less pretentious, more casual brother to Yoshi's, without live music, and in a cozier home.

Aside from the ambience, the staff was very friendly and helpful.  The folks delivering our food placed the plates on our table with little jokes and spritely remarks. 

The food itself was delectable.  While pricey, I'd say the food is well worth it. 

Here's the run-down of what we divulged in:
Hawaiian Style Tuna Poke - delicious, nice flavors, but not groundbreaking in terms of innovative flavors, yet still worth the price.
Small crudos, spicy tuna and scallop - once again delicious: tuna tasted fresh, seasoning was good, but I particularly enjoyed the scallop.
Fire Cracker Balls - Yelp tips told us to get it. The Fire Cracker Balls were indeed crackin'.
Domo Roll - I'm not a fan of the Lion King roll to begin with, but this roll changed my mind for the night.
Kobe Beef - as an unusual item, we obviously had to try this. Verdict: The beef was well seasoned, and the roll itself was rich and creamy (because of the avocado). Overall, I'd re-order, yes.
Mac Daddy - daddy got it right. delicious.

Thanks for the meal, Domo.

excerpts: Hawaiian Style Tuna Poke: sooo yummy!
hawaiian style tuna poke.author: Mia L.
hawaiian style tuna poke.review:
I really liked Domo.  The sushi was fresh and flavorful.  The Ankimo (monkfish liver) was fresh and clean tasting, unlike most other places I've had it.  Other must tries:

Fire Cracker Balls: crunchy, spicy, addicting
Sexy Mama Roll: lemony fresh and tasty
Spicy Hulk Roll: wrapped in cucumber gives it awesome fresh flavor and texture
Hawaiian Style Tuna Poke: sooo yummy!

Overall definitely one of the better sushi bars in SF. Get there early, it's tiny and theres always a line.

excerpts: I got the seared albacore tataki, the fiesta roll, and the I.C. roll.
Seared albacore tataki--so spot on and so
so so delicious.
Would highly recommend you order this if you go!
The albacore slices are super generous and the ponzu sauce just completes it perfectly.
I''d definitely consider just eating this as a whole meal.
Seared albacore tataki--so spot on and so
so so delicious.
Would highly recommend you order this if you go!
The albacore slices are super generous and the ponzu sauce just completes it perfectly.
I''d definitely consider just eating this as a whole meal.
tldr; meh not as good as I think Yelp makes it out to be, though the seared albacore tataki is spot on
tldr; meh not as good as I think Yelp makes it out to be, though the seared albacore tataki is spot on
seared albacore tataki.author: Jasmine X.
seared albacore tataki.review:
Eh I wasn't a huge fan of this place, probably because although I do love Chinese food, when I'm eating Japanese food, I'm a purist at heart and can't deal with these not Japanese Japanese joints.

Anyways, I came here for dinner on Sunday right when they opened and it was insane how quickly they filled up. I got there about five minutes after opening and all the indoor seats were already taken. Luckily, they have a few tables outside which are actually really  nice since weather in SF has been pretty good. They're also more fun if you want to people watch. I also personally liked the outside seating more because the inside smelled really oily and restuaranty. 

I got the seared albacore tataki, the fiesta roll, and the I.C. roll. Part of me regrets not following what other Yelpers suggested, but I'm just not really a fan of unagi so some of the more popular rolls wouldn't have made much sense for me.

Seared albacore tataki--so spot on and so so so delicious. Would highly recommend you order this if you go! The albacore slices are super generous and the ponzu sauce just completes it perfectly. I''d definitely consider just eating this as a whole meal. It's five slices per order, so if I ever go back, I'd be down for two of these lol.

The rolls... were not so great. Pretty mediocre rolls. The fish cuts were really thin and not worth it. Rolls were fine but nothing special. I liked I.C. enough, but I honestly felt like both rolls were super mediocre. 

All in all, price came out to be about $20/person without tax which wasn't too bad since we didn't eat too much.

tldr; meh not as good as I think Yelp makes it out to be, though the seared albacore tataki is spot on

excerpts: They also had salmon toro baked in salt, which makes for a crispy skinned rich fatty morsel, smoky and salty like pork belly but with much better mouthfeel.
Definitely eat the skin right along with the fish.
salmon toro baked.author: Sean B.
salmon toro baked.review:
I've got a few staples I use to test a new sushi joint, and Domo executed nearly flawlessly on all of them, as well as having new and wonderful dishes I'd not heard of before.

Their saba, one of my favorite nigiri and a great test of restaurant and chef, was impressive. Soft, lightly acidic, with excellent rich mackerel flavor but no heavy oily fishiness that can happen so easily. It's obviously cured in-house, and quite well. Their ankimo is tasty and the presentation is lovely. It's not too much, either, which is nice for what should be an appetizer. Their hamachi kama is delicious and very generous with the fish. Huge hunks of creamy salty goodness and a piquant dipping sauce. They had hamachi toro, which was fun to try but not as good as bluefin toro. They also had salmon toro baked in salt, which makes for a crispy skinned rich fatty morsel, smoky and salty like pork belly but with much better mouthfeel. Definitely eat the skin right along with the fish. Good rolls with inventive combinations, although a bit heavy on the deep frying.

Service was fast and informative, and the price was right. We three dined well and left full for $95 without tip, including a few beers (no Asahi, but the Asahi Dark was a nice complement to the fatty foods we ordered.)

excerpts: We ordered the Hamachi Cappachio to start and this was my favorite out of all the sushi we tried-
it was very fresh and the flavors were great.
hamachi cappachio.author: Natalie M.
hamachi cappachio.review: I was worried we would have to wait a really long time since we were a party of five and there's only one table in addition to bar seating. Luckily, we only waited ten minutes, at the very most and then we did our best to fit around the table with all of our water glasses and plates- it was a tight squeeze, and our waiter did his best to accommodate our group. We ordered the Hamachi Cappachio to start and this was my favorite out of all the sushi we tried- it was very fresh and the flavors were great. The fiesta roll sounded interesting because I like tuna, mango and cilantro, but it's actually kind of weird to have salsa on your sushi so I'll never order that roll again. We also ordered the spider roll and one other that I forget the name of; I liked both of them and found that everything tasted fresh with a great mix of spices and flavors. I can't wait to go back and try some of the other rolls!

excerpts: The Sunazuri (hamachi belly) is my favorite.
sunazuri.author: Jocelyn B.
sunazuri.review:
Domo arigato!

Domo has indefinitely claimed the rights to my favorite place to find fresh fish and creative rolls. We ordered "omakase" (chef's choice) and this is why we got to try a little bit of everything that makes Domo so special.

The Spicy Hulk - with spicy tuna, avo, and ponzu wrapped up in cucumber. This is a nice change from the heavy rice in most rolls. The texture is an interesting element and the plate a beautiful piece of art. 

The Kobe Beef roll with asparagus, ginger, avacado, ponzu was also an interesting flavor/texture. The Fish Taco, nori tempura fried with fresh sashimi and homemade pepper salsa - delicious! A must order.

It seems that Domo does really well creatively. Both the design of the dish and the presentation are flawless. Its easy to bring friends here and be assured that everyone will find something they enjoy.

but....fresh fish- Thats what I really come to places like this for. I want sashimi, I want nigiri. Omakase gifted our taste-buds with so many cuts of beautifully colored fish. *happy happy girl* The Sunazuri (hamachi belly) is my favorite.

excerpts: The sunazuri (hamachi belly), which was a fantastic deal at $5.25 for two pieces, was light and clean.
The sake (salmon) was presented as a rose, which is a trend these days, and was smooth and buttery.
Unlike the sunazuri, though, it was nothing to write home about.
Then we tried the tazmanian trout, which was really something.
It was my first time having it and the taste, while similar to salmon, had a bit more texture.
There isn't an extremely wide selection of fish or sake like there is at, say, Sushi Bistro, but they do have some stand-outs with the sunazuri and trout, which you may not necessarily get elsewhere.
They also have shiro maguro (albacore) which is also a delicacy that not all sushi bars may necessarily serve.
Plus the sake is a super good deal--nice 'small' bottle for $7!
I wouldn't mind coming back but most likely
I wouldn't unless I happen to be in the area.
sunazuri.author: Tiffany H.
sunazuri.review:
Came here on a whim a little before 7PM on a Friday night and was fortunate to arrive before things got busy.  The place seats about 18-20ish with customers eating on high chairs over counters.  Some face the chef and the sushi bar, others face the wall and/or the window.

The small crudos were a rip-off in my opinion--literally two spoonfuls for $5.95.  We ordered the scallop and ankimo.  For ankimo that size, it would probably have been more worth it to pay the $8 and get it as an appetizer.  Taste-wise, though, both dishes were fine.

Unfortunately, we didn't get a chance to try many of the fusion rolls, which judging from other reviewers seem to be a high point of this place, but we tried the sushi and sashimi.  The sunazuri (hamachi belly), which was a fantastic deal at $5.25 for two pieces, was light and clean.  The sake (salmon) was presented as a rose, which is a trend these days, and was smooth and buttery.  Unlike the sunazuri, though, it was nothing to write home about.  Then we tried the tazmanian trout, which was really something.  It was my first time having it and the taste, while similar to salmon, had a bit more texture.  Those who find salmon too 'slimy' might appreciate trout more.

We finished things off with a rock & roll but it was truly mediocre.  I've had rock & roll from a food court in Irvine l that was better than this.  If you want a really good rock & roll, go to Kirala in Berkeley.

Still, the overall experience was pleasant.  My impression of Domo is that it's very affordable given the quality of food.  There isn't an extremely wide selection of fish or sake like there is at, say, Sushi Bistro, but they do have some stand-outs with the sunazuri and trout, which you may not necessarily get elsewhere.  They also have shiro maguro (albacore) which is also a delicacy that not all sushi bars may necessarily serve.  Plus the sake is a super good deal--nice 'small' bottle for $7!  I wouldn't mind coming back but most likely I wouldn't unless I happen to be in the area.

excerpts: My top pick is the sunazuri when there is no toro.
The sushi is innovative and interesting.
The rolls are unlike other ones I've had.
sunazuri.author: Jennifer W.
sunazuri.review:
The smaller the place, the more I like it. I love the intimate setting here, a few tables outside and all counter inside. It has some nice woodwork and a large mirror to lend itself some space. The specials written on that mirror should not be missed. Usually there is a croquette or some seasonal fish on there as well as special rolls not listed on the menu. The service is great. Portions are small, but leaves me satisfied.

I am a fan of the lunch specials. There is a small, but apt selection that comes with miso soup and an iceberg lettuce wedge with housemade dressing. The dressing is sweet, sour, and refreshing. The fish is incredibly fresh. Go with the chirashi or some nigiri. My top pick is the sunazuri when there is no toro. The sushi is innovative and interesting. The rolls are unlike other ones I've had. The Domo roll was baked and tender. The crunchy spicy tuna was not that crunchy, but had a thick layer of tempura batter, which was even more exaggerated because it was sliced diagonally. The kobe beef roll was delicious and juicy. The beef was sliced incredibly thin and it was really tender. The avocado and asparagus inside was good. Same with the cucumber roll, good use of a different type of wrap than the usual nori. I don't like that some rolls are heavily drizzled with a lot of the same house sauce. Some rolls I wish I could taste without the sauce or just with soy sauce. Also, I wonder if they will serve omakase here...

excerpts: Sunazuri (hamachi belly)
sunazuri.author: Rodney A.
sunazuri.review:
My number 1 sushi spot to go to in the Bay Area.  Reasonably priced and good quality fish.

Best thing about this place is the chill and relaxed vibe and the head chef/manager Ryo.  I've become a regular here and he definitely knows his fish and his technique is impeccable.  Sit at the bar, order from him and he'll take care of you.

For me a sign of a good chef is one that's constantly tasting his food, making sure that it's up to his standards of taste and quality.  I've had the pleasure of sitting in front of the sushi bar and watching Ryo break down the complicated structure of a flying fish, all the while tasting different cuts and making sure they were excellent. Over the next few weeks he refined his marinade and cure for his flying fish to the point that he really brought out its beautiful flavors without sacrificing the fish's great texture.

It's a common misconception that sushi is the freshest fish available when in fact most sushi is aged, marinated, or cured for a few days before serving.  There in lies some of the art to great sushi, and at Domo, Ryo knows how to treat the fish he gets.  I'm a sushi purist.  Give me your nigiri, give me your sashimi.  I don't really care for sushi rolls but I've had them and they don't disappoint either.  Before Domo I used to HATE mackerel.  At other sushi places, the fishiness of mackerel would be overpowering.  At Domo, Ryo prepares his mackerel carefully and in small batches and the outcome is a fresh fish taste and texture.  I love the mackerel at Domo, and I believe that he elevates all of the other fish he receives to a higher degree than most other sushi spots at the same price point.  Along those same lines, a sign of a really good chef is consistency. If I like a restaurant, I'll always return a few times, and when it comes to sushi I'll invariably have bad visits - times when I'll find a bone in my sushi or the fish won't be up to par.  This hasn't been the case at Domo.  I've been several times and it's always been wonderful.

My faves on the menu:
Fish Tacos - Love the tempura fried nori.  I always ask him to go light on the salsa.

Sea urchin crudo - He pairs his urchin with avocado, and it reinforces the butteryness of the urchin while mellowing out the oceany flavor.

Ankimo (monk fish liver) crudo - a simple presentation and take on ankimo and it's really good.

Sake toro (salmon belly)
Sunazuri (hamachi belly)
Ryo has a great way of balancing out the fattyness of these cuts with something bright and refreshing be it a thin, thin slice of kumquat or some pickled ginger.

And again, ask him for what he's got and what's "fresh" Ryo is great at showcasing some of his fresh batches and what's in season.  Some of my faves off-menu have been:

Flying fish - great texture and mild flavor
Half Beak - a firmer, smoother texture than most fish but delicious
Walu (butterfish) - cured well with an almost sweet/buttery flavor
Black Snapper
Red Snapper

Come to Domo, sit at the bar, order sushi, and enjoy - rinse, wash and repeat.  You won't be disappointed.

excerpts:
Like a fried spicy tuna roll, but in ball form

He ordered the: 
Nigiri: Toro [fatty tuna], Sunazuri [Hamachi belly], Hotate [scallop]
sunazuri.author: Tinna H.
sunazuri.review:
The layout here is very strange. If all the seats were packed, the people in the corners would be sitting on top of each other or would be stuck in their chairs unable to move. No bathroom break for you! I know, they're just trying to make the most out of the space. Luckily, when we arrived on a Sunday evening for dinner, it wasn't too packed, and the people on the same corner were on their way out.

We shared the: 
Kobe Beef + Asparagus Tataki
Firecracker Balls: Like a fried spicy tuna roll, but in ball form

He ordered the: 
Nigiri: Toro [fatty tuna], Sunazuri [Hamachi belly], Hotate [scallop]

I ordered the:
Sashimi Combo: Hamachi [yellow tail], Sake [salmon], Maguro [tuna], Albacore

The fish was fresh and tasty. My friend only had good things to say about the nigiri he ordered. He was treating me to a belated birthday dinner, but both of us left ready for a second meal. Perhaps we should have ordered a bowl of rice on the side. Or maybe we are just pigs. 

It's just okay unless you plan on getting some jive ass rolls [http://www.yelp.com/biz/jive-ass-roll-san-francisco].

excerpts: Sunazuri (yellowtail belly), maguro, and
albacore was great.
The crudos were well worth it, I had the monkfish liver and the salmon.
Both had great taste and were presented beautifully.
I love shiso, so the spicy tuna roll was perfect for me.
The guys behind the counter and friendly and interactive, not stand-offish like some places.
They offer you some off the menu things if you butter them up a little.
Service for water or tea refills could be hard to get.
For the price, this is a good find.
Its not a destination restaurant, but
if you want a good local place, this is superior to most.
Beats tourist traps and isn't pricey like Sebo.
sunazuri.author: Christian W.
sunazuri.review: Wow, this is a great addition to the neighborhood.  My impression is possibly enhanced by the great day in GG park under the sun, but the fish was so nourishing.  Sunazuri (yellowtail belly), maguro, and albacore was great.  The crudos were well worth it, I had the monkfish liver and the salmon.  Both had great taste and were presented beautifully.  I love shiso, so the spicy tuna roll was perfect for me.  The guys behind the counter and friendly and interactive, not stand-offish like some places.  They offer you some off the menu things if you butter them up a little.  Service for water or tea refills could be hard to get.  For the price, this is a good find.  Its not a destination restaurant, but if you want a good local place, this is superior to most.  Beats tourist traps and isn't pricey like Sebo.

excerpts: I opted for the spicy tuna and seared albacore and they were what you'd except.
seared albacore.author: Benjamin F.
seared albacore.review:
I stopped into Domo this past week for a quick business lunch as it's one of the few sushi spots open in Hayes Valley at noon. I've eaten at Domo a few times before and always found it to be pretty run of the mill sushi. I'm not knocking this place but, it's one of those sushi spots that gives you an experience like you'd expect for basic sushi. The only difference is that Domo is more expensive than what you're getting. 

I ordered the lunch special which was a solid deal. 14.99 for soup, salad and your choice of two proteins on top of rice. I opted for the spicy tuna and seared albacore and they were what you'd except. I also ordered a side of ikura nigiri and they were decent. 

Look. The fish is good, just good. If you're looking for a casual sushi spot in an intimate setting then it's a good option.

seared albacore.author: Jasmine X.
seared albacore.review:
Eh I wasn't a huge fan of this place, probably because although I do love Chinese food, when I'm eating Japanese food, I'm a purist at heart and can't deal with these not Japanese Japanese joints.

Anyways, I came here for dinner on Sunday right when they opened and it was insane how quickly they filled up. I got there about five minutes after opening and all the indoor seats were already taken. Luckily, they have a few tables outside which are actually really  nice since weather in SF has been pretty good. They're also more fun if you want to people watch. I also personally liked the outside seating more because the inside smelled really oily and restuaranty. 

I got the seared albacore tataki, the fiesta roll, and the I.C. roll. Part of me regrets not following what other Yelpers suggested, but I'm just not really a fan of unagi so some of the more popular rolls wouldn't have made much sense for me.

Seared albacore tataki--so spot on and so so so delicious. Would highly recommend you order this if you go! The albacore slices are super generous and the ponzu sauce just completes it perfectly. I''d definitely consider just eating this as a whole meal. It's five slices per order, so if I ever go back, I'd be down for two of these lol.

The rolls... were not so great. Pretty mediocre rolls. The fish cuts were really thin and not worth it. Rolls were fine but nothing special. I liked I.C. enough, but I honestly felt like both rolls were super mediocre. 

All in all, price came out to be about $20/person without tax which wasn't too bad since we didn't eat too much.

tldr; meh not as good as I think Yelp makes it out to be, though the seared albacore tataki is spot on

excerpts: We then moved onto the fishies and tried the hamachi belly, the scallops and the seared albacore.
All were totally tasty and definitely melt on the tongue succulent.
We also tried the firecracker balls and they were good, but not great.
They weren't very spicy at all
seared albacore.author: Stephy S.
seared albacore.review:
Do you ever walk by something so many times that you kind of forget it's even there? I've had this phenomenon happen with work deadlines, boyfriends and laundry, but this time, wow, there is a sushi place here? Sweet.

After being turned away from Absinthe due to lights out and "oh yeah, duh, they are closed on Monday," we decided to try Suppenküche. Then after being seated at a table right by the cold drafty door and factoring in the fact that it was way too crowded to even hear ourselves guzzle beer or slurp egg noodles, we decided to give Domo a long overdue go. 

We were seated facing out the window immediately and with the rainy night, it made for some fun people watching. Since we had been drinking wine for a couple hours prior, we decided to stick with that and ordered the only red they had, a Pinot Noir, and I can say with a large amount of certainty that, yikes, it wasn't very good.

We then moved onto the fishies and tried the hamachi belly, the scallops and the seared albacore. All were totally tasty and definitely melt on the tongue succulent. We also tried the firecracker balls and they were good, but not great. They weren't very spicy at all and since I've only ever had them before at Red Box Sushi in the Loin, I would say they weren't as good as RBS. 

Overall, it was a decent little snack and affordable. The service was quick and efficient and I would pop in there again if I was in the neighborhood. Would I rush to it? Nah, I'd sooner hit Sushi Zone on Market or Warakabune on Church

excerpts:
"  

Okey, on to the others: uni (sissy portions), the uni/monkfish liver sushi crudo combo (more sissy portions), seared albacore nigiri (came to us non-seared, equally sissy), and the $14 sashimi salad
seared albacore.author: Ken W.
seared albacore.review:
I'll start with the good things and then work my way down.  
*Nice cozy place and atmosphere in a hood surrounded by other cozy restaurants.  
*I thought the service was good and attentive.  The waitress said they were running out of hot sake but managed to squeeze out two bottles out of the box for us.
*The Spicy Hulk was actually spicy, cool, and refreshing...our favorite of the night.

The specials scribbled on the mirror were hard to read...we constantly had to bobble our heads in order to see what was up.  One of the specials was the Fresh Ikura so we asked for it.

"We're out of it."  Ok, how about the not-so-fresh ikura?  
"We're out of that too."  

Okey, on to the others: uni (sissy portions), the uni/monkfish liver sushi crudo combo (more sissy portions), seared albacore nigiri (came to us non-seared, equally sissy), and the $14 sashimi salad (We got what looked like one expensive head of lettuce compared to the amount of sashimi in it, and the dressing was bland).  The way they hold back on the portions I was surprised they would be out of anything...from my experience most Chinese-owned sushi shops are rather generous with their portions but this joint plays this neighborhood.

$.02

excerpts: Chefs choice sashimi, the fish tasted fresh and was a good portion for the price compared to other places in SF.
chefs choice.author: Morgan B.
chefs choice.review:
Called ahead to ask about seating and was told there would be space enough for my party of 4. We arrive and they seat us at a tall table in the corner that was really only big enough for 2 people, we were crammed into the corner. 

That aside, we went ahead and ordered. 

The $15 crf of sake I ordered was HALF the size of every other sushi place I've been to. It only filled 1 tiny sake glass for each of the 4 of us. 4 shots of sake for $15. No thanks. I asked what seemed to be the manager about the size of the crf and he said, "no, it's right. This is our size. This is the size we serve." Don't come here if you like to have drinks with your sushi. Severely overpriced. 

The rolls were really average, nothing bad about them but nothing remarkable about them either. Same sushi rolls you can get anywhere else.

The sashimi was the only redeeming thing about eating here. Chefs choice sashimi, the fish tasted fresh and was a good portion for the price compared to other places in SF. 

Would not recommend for sake drinkers or sushi enthusiasts. Might be a good place for those who only want sashimi and don't care about the rest.

excerpts: Unfortunately, the chefs choice sashimi platter isn't the freshest.
You have to get the specials to get the better, more fresh fish but obviously much pricier.
chefs choice.author: Rohenne L.
chefs choice.review:
Cute place and super cozy! (If you want to go on a date where you're sitting VERY close to each other, this is probably a good place). However, it's definitely a more "western" sushi place. Unfortunately, the chefs choice sashimi platter isn't the freshest. You have to get the specials to get the better, more fresh fish but obviously much pricier.  The sashimi is cut super thick unlike how Japanese sushi places do it.

Overall not a bad experience and not expensive. I'd rather pay a bit more for authentic Japanese omakase. I wouldn't come back unfortunately.

excerpts: I started with a sweet potato roll and a red dragon roll (on special) - both great!
I also ordered a hot sake, and put in a second sushi order:
sake (salmon) nigiri and another sweet potato roll.
sweet potato.author: Bri T.
sweet potato.review:
I waited 20 minutes for a table, but it's a small place so it was not surprising. I had never been here before and didn't do any research in advance, so didn't know what I was getting myself into. Thankfully, everything was delicious! I started with a sweet potato roll and a red dragon roll (on special) - both great! I also ordered a hot sake, and put in a second sushi order: sake (salmon) nigiri and another sweet potato roll. My server was attentive and made great suggestions throughout the evening, and it was great sitting at the sushi bar. 

Great food, and an enjoyable experience. The restaurant was pretty dark but not so much so that I could not read the menu. Highly recommend!

excerpts: Sweet Potato Roll -
I'm super lame and had to order the non-fishy food
and there's not a lot of non-seafood items here, unless you want miso soup and edamame.
Don't expect bento boxes of teriyaki chicken and udon because this place serves lots of fish and sushi..
The sweet potato roll was really good!
Tempura fried sweet potato wrapped in rice and seaweed and then topped with teriyaki sauce (i'm guessing?)
sweet potato.author: Carmen C.
sweet potato.review:
I was craving sushi and then yelped this place. Pretty good reviews for their fish taco and Domo roll, so I decided to check it out! Not bad!!! Their fish tacos are delicious! Their daily specials are written on a huge mirrored wall. Not a lot of seating, but come early and it should be fine! Parking was a little of a hassle, but definitely manageable. Food comes out one by one.. so if you're starving... patience... patience... I nearly scarfed down every single plate that came by slowly.. 

Monkfish liver pate- personally didn't eat this, but my friend says its just alright... the presentation was wonderful though, served on a soup spoon

Uni- looks delicious, didn't eat it because I'm not a fan, but according to my friend, he says it's really good! very fresh!

Fish tacos - they're not your typical fish tacos that you'd get at a taqueria or some Taco Tuesday...the plate comes with 2 "tacos".. it's a piece of albacore with a piece of salmon served on a crispy fried nori, topped with salsa and sriracha... i can't even begin to describe how all of this tastes in your mouth... sooo good! unlike anything i've ever tasted! I definitely recommend ordering this if you come here! Sadly, the whole "taco" falls apart after a few bites..

Walu (Hawaiian Butterfish) - pretty good! Don't know how else to describe this

Domo Roll - this seemed very popular on Yelp, so I decided to order this, but I wasn't really blown away. It's pretty much a California roll topped with salmon and scallop and baked.  It reminded me of a Dragon roll because I could barely taste the scallops.. 

Sweet Potato Roll - I'm super lame and had to order the non-fishy food and there's not a lot of non-seafood items here, unless you want miso soup and edamame. Don't expect bento boxes of teriyaki chicken and udon because this place serves lots of fish and sushi.. The sweet potato roll was really good! Tempura fried sweet potato wrapped in rice and seaweed and then topped with teriyaki sauce (i'm guessing?) 

California Roll - I hear the crab meat is made from real crab, so I ordered this... To be honest, I couldn't really tell the difference.. maybe it seemed to have a little more of a crabmeat like texture and maybe a little fishier. I wouldn't order this again because there's so many other things to try here!

excerpts: but none the less I tried their sweet potato roll, and a avocado roll
, both were absolutely Devine, this is a cute place to sit at the window and watch people while eating with a friend.
Very fast friendly service also.
Parking wasn't to hard to find.
sweet potato.author: Nelanne C.
sweet potato.review: So my review may be biased since I cannot eat fish or shellfish so I usually don't eat sushi but none the less I tried their sweet potato roll, and a avocado roll, both were absolutely Devine, this is a cute place to sit at the window and watch people while eating with a friend. Very fast friendly service also. Parking wasn't to hard to find.

excerpts:
So deliciously paired with the avocado

Spicy tuna roll- pretty good and not that spicy 

Sweet potato roll- amazing!!!
sweet potato.author: Tamara D.
sweet potato.review:
Just finished up lunch at Domo... And can't say I didn't leave with a happy stomach and smile on my face. 
Food:
Crudo- salmon and scallops... The salmon was amazing!!! So deliciously paired with the avocado

Spicy tuna roll- pretty good and not that spicy 

Sweet potato roll- amazing!!! Like French fries but way better!!!!

Hamachi roll- usually love hamachi but this was just okay 

Overall good experience.. Pretty busy for lunch and there was only one server, so service was a little slow but not too bad

excerpts: We were seated another 20 mins later and skimmed through the menu before deciding on the above plus the Sweet Potato roll ($4) and the Salmon Avocado roll ($6.50 I think).
The crunchy roll was just about the best thing I've ever tasted.
It had cooked tuna which resembled meat loaf, avocado, tobiko and spicy mayo
and then the whole thing was battered and fried.
I don't really enjoy spicy food but this was nice and complemented the other flavors well.
I didn't eat the sweet potato or salmon and avocado rolls, but my friend really enjoyed them, especially the sweet potato roll.
I'm so happy I came here and went the adventurous route
; I would've completely missed out had I not!
The only thing I have to complain about is the size.
This place is so freakin small
and you're basically seated at a wrap-around bar
sweet potato.author: Amanda C.
sweet potato.review:
So, this was my second stop in San Francisco and my first time trying what I'd now call mildly adventurous sushi. 

Up until tonight, I was completely excited by inside out avocado rolls. But, I decided to try something new and ordered the Spicy Hulk roll ($9.50) and on my friends recommendation, the Crunchy Spicy Tuna roll ($11). We were told the wait was 20 mins so we went to grab a drink but when we came back they had already called our names so we told the guy and he signed us up for the next spot. We were seated another 20 mins later and skimmed through the menu before deciding on the above plus the Sweet Potato roll ($4) and the Salmon Avocado roll ($6.50 I think). The crunchy roll was just about the best thing I've ever tasted. It had cooked tuna which resembled meat loaf, avocado, tobiko and spicy mayo and then the whole thing was battered and fried. I don't really enjoy spicy food but this was nice and complemented the other flavors well. The Spicy Hulk roll was tuna mashed up (looked like ground beef), avocado, a tiny bit of tobiko and all wrapped up by a piece of cucumber in a spicy sauce that was like lemony soy sauce (ponzu?). I didn't like this at all...the texture freaked me out and I felt like I was eating cat food. It also might have been less enjoyable because I had it after the Crunchy roll. I didn't eat the sweet potato or salmon and avocado rolls, but my friend really enjoyed them, especially the sweet potato roll. I'm so happy I came here and went the adventurous route; I would've completely missed out had I not! The only thing I have to complain about is the size. This place is so freakin small and you're basically seated at a wrap-around bar so you don't get to really face your friends and have a conversation. 

Hope I get to stop in again before I leave!

excerpts: As a primarily veganish eater, I had the sweet potato roll and the veggie roll.
Both were big and just two rolls are enough for a whole dinner (especially when sharing a beer and sake!)
However, one item on the menu could not be ignored, fish tacos!
Yes, gorgeous little tacos, the perfect mix of Japanese and Mexican.
Lovely, light, tasty, perfection!
I ate one!
I did.
I didn't die.
sweet potato.author: Valerie L.
sweet potato.review:
This is a super cute and cozy sushi spot located on a picturesque corner in charming Hayes Valley. The menu has a great combo of traditional sushi and Americanized "sushi," and there is some fun fusion thrown in. As a primarily veganish eater, I had the sweet potato roll and the veggie roll. Both were big and just two rolls are enough for a whole dinner (especially when sharing a beer and sake!) However, one item on the menu could not be ignored, fish tacos! Yes, gorgeous little tacos, the perfect mix of Japanese and Mexican. Lovely, light, tasty, perfection! I ate one! I did. I didn't die. It was great. 

On a beautiful, warm spring night in San Francisco, eat at Domo! Gaze out at the people passing by, or even sit outside!

The only downside to this place is that it is all bar all around unless you sit outside. Thus, it wouldn't be great for a group larger than three (unless you don't converse), and even with relatively thin people, it can get kinda squishy. 

I'm going back as soon as I find a willing and eager dining partner!

excerpts: Had a seaweed salad (good) and some rolls: crunchy spicy tuna (meh- a little too tempura for me), sweet potato (now this one should've been crispy, in my opinion), salmon/avocado/lemon (gross-
sweet potato.author: Meade G.
sweet potato.review:
San Francisco has some awesome sushi places, but my experience at Domo was just average. I had been here a couple of years ago, and it was more delicious back then. I came the other night with a friend. Had a seaweed salad (good) and some rolls: crunchy spicy tuna (meh- a little too tempura for me), sweet potato (now this one should've been crispy, in my opinion), salmon/avocado/lemon (gross- the fish just did NOT seem fresh; had two pieces and let the rest go to waste). 

Probably won't  be back anytime soon. Too many other great sushi places that charge the same or less for better tasting fish.

excerpts:
Sweet Potato roll - ok.
Mac Daddy - delicious.
Sweet Mamma - delicious.
sweet potato.author: Nilu r.
sweet potato.review:
Cute little place...and I mean little, this place is tiny. It can be very romantic as you snuggle up at the counter but when it is full it is loud and cramped. 
The lighting is lovely, the view onto Laguna street from the counter is very cute...you almost forget you are in Hayes valley, flanked on all sides by ghetto. Oh yeah I hate Hayes valley.  I did not hate Domo however. I actually really really like this place.

We tried:

tuna poki - a creative version of poki with octopus which was very very delicious.
Fish tacos - SOOOOOOOO good. the best thing I ate there.
Sweet Potato roll - ok.
Mac Daddy - delicious.
Sweet Mamma - delicious.
Hamachi / Jalapeno roll - great.

The service was great, we were full and happy ad paid out about $100 for the two of us.  Admittedly this was a bit overpriced especially considering that the seating was not very comfortable and the fish was good but not "knock your shoes off memorable"...I may be back but probably not soon (Hayes Valley issues). 
Still, I would give 4 stars to Domo.

excerpts: The sweet potato roll was awesome.
It was fried and all creamy inside.
It was pretty amazing how satisfied I was with some potatoes and rice.
sweet potato.author: Julia N.
sweet potato.review:
I'll admit it. Our first choice for dinner was not Domo. We were originally going to dine at Suppenkuche but the wait was an hour so we started meandering around to find something else. 

Domo has virtually no seating inside so I was shocked that we were able to get the ONE table that they had in the corner (there were four of us).  Everything is bar seating so this is NOT a good spot for large parties. 

The sweet potato roll was awesome. It was fried and all creamy inside. It was pretty amazing how satisfied I was with some potatoes and rice.

excerpts: To go for: Spicy Hulk, Firecracker Balls, Fish Tacos, Sweet potato maki.
sweet potato.author: Rika P.
sweet potato.review:
Small and intimate, Domo squeezes up modern sushi enthusiasts to fit their capacity of 20 people (the most). Very creative menu, crafty sushi masters, colorful dishes.

To go for: Spicy Hulk, Firecracker Balls, Fish Tacos, Sweet potato maki.
Specials are written on their only mirrored wall, also worth checking it out. 

I don't think they take reservations, but if you have to wait, be patient. This place is worth waiting for. Fish is always fresh, service is nothing to complain about, and overall atmosphere is great!

excerpts: I always get the sweet potato roll and the firecracker balls.
sweet potato.author: Angel P.
sweet potato.review:
YUMMM! Just thinking about this place makes me hungry! I love everything about Domo, from it's decor to the food. I've rarely had to wait very long but I usually only come with one other person. There is no room in here for a large group. The prices seem fair compared to other places in the city. 

I always get the sweet potato roll and the firecracker balls. The Spicy Hulk is probably the my all time favorite. I could eat a whole order by myself!!

excerpts: We ordered a spider roll and a spicy CA roll and a sweet potato roll.
The sweet potato roll was nothing to write home about, and I liked bf's CA roll better than the spider roll I ordered.
Super tasty, nom nom.
I like!
sweet potato.author: Cheryl F.
sweet potato.review:
Really cute, pretty little sushi bar, but really expensive! Who charges $14 for a roll of rice, a tiny bit of fish smothered in sauce? Sadly, every place in SF, and I will gladly pay for it, which is why that now that I'm a resident of Hayes Valley and a pescatarian, I'll be hitting up this place probably more often than my wallet would like.

Came here with the boyfriend after we moved in my stuff to my new house. I'd heard about this place and we couldn't find it until we Yelped, and then had to wait about 10 minutes for a spot at the bar. There was one lone 3-person round table that apparently couldn't be occupied for whatever reason as they were seating all patrons at the bar. 

The sushi came out at a reasonable time. I like how our waiter brought our Asahi right away and poured it out into two cups for us. We ordered a spider roll and a spicy CA roll and a sweet potato roll. The sweet potato roll was nothing to write home about, and I liked bf's CA roll better than the spider roll I ordered. Super tasty, nom nom. I like!

excerpts:
- Sweet potato maki (MUST GET)
- Shiitake mushroom maki (MUST GET)
- Hamachi and jalapeno 
(yes, spicy sushi!)
- Firecracker balls
- Salmon Nigiri
- california roll
- black sesame ice cream (I love this, and order it wherever I see it -- which isn't very often)
sweet potato.author: Jenny S.
sweet potato.review:
A shockingly good, intimate restaurant in the din of Hayes Valley that makes me hesitant to write a review at all for fear that word will get out.

The fish here is really fresh, and is what I would call novelty sushi. I tried a lot of things here I wouldn't normally find at other sushi places, but the menu would probably elicit a big WTF from a japanese person if they saw some of the menu items (is hamachi plus jalapenos a faux pas? so delicious!).

- Sweet potato maki (MUST GET)
- Shiitake mushroom maki (MUST GET)
- Hamachi and jalapeno (yes, spicy sushi!)
- Firecracker balls
- Salmon Nigiri
- california roll
- black sesame ice cream (I love this, and order it wherever I see it -- which isn't very often)

excerpts: And the prices were very fair - $9 for the fire cracker balls (again so good) and $4 for the sweet potato roll (also delic).
I would def go there again!
sweet potato.author: Ka C.
sweet potato.review:
SOOO YUMMIE!!! I had the fire cracker balls -to die for and trust me I like some good balls in my mouth but these were exceptional! 

Only lost a star because of the size, very intimate good for a date or small party (3 or less). Lovely relaxing atmosphere and good music. 

Service was wonderful. We had the only table in the place and they didn't rush us at all, even when another party of 4 came through the door. 

And the prices were very fair - $9 for the fire cracker balls (again so good) and $4 for the sweet potato roll (also delic). I would def go there again!

excerpts:
Here's what we ate:
- edamame
- salmon nigiri
- hamachi nigiri
- ikura nigiri
- sweet potato roll
- rock & roll
- spicy tuna
- and a small bottle of inexpensive cold sweet unfiltered sake

All I can say is
sweet potato.author: Wendy K.
sweet potato.review:
What a pleasant surprise! My S.O. and I planned to attend a party in Hayes Valley last night, and I asked a friend for places to eat dinner before the party in the neighborhood. She recommended Domo b/c her husband had eaten there before. Sold! This was the perfect spot for my "congratulations-on-finally-getting-a-job-as-a-librarian" dinner with my S.O.

We arrived at 7:30 PM, put our names down, and only had to wait about 15 min. And those 15 min. passed quickly thanks to the cold unfiltered sake that we shared while waiting.

We were seated in the corner along the window, which was a great experience. I don't know about you, but it's rare that my S.O. and I sit next to each other while dining, unless we're eating on the couch and watching TV together. I would definitely recommend Domo for couples and not larger dinner parties, as it would be difficult for more people to talk at the counter together. There is only one round table in the corner, and all of the other seats are along counters or the sushi bar.

Here's what we ate:
- edamame
- salmon nigiri
- hamachi nigiri
- ikura nigiri
- sweet potato roll
- rock & roll
- spicy tuna
- and a small bottle of inexpensive cold sweet unfiltered sake

All I can say is Wow. The fish melted in our mouths. My S.O. usually measures sushi restaurants by the quality of their ikura, and so we've sampled it at a lot of different places. The ikura here was by far the best I've ever had. Clearly fresh, it lacked the fishy taste that we've experienced at other restaurants. I measure sushi restaurants by their spicy tuna, and while the taste wasn't exactly the same as my favorite place in Boston, Domo's was good in its own right. Fresh fish, spicy!, and crispy cucumber all did a little dance in my mouth. Best of all, we we were both surprised that the total bill wasn't more expensive. No, please don't raise your prices or shrink your portions!

I wish I could give Domo 4.5 stars. It doesn't earn a complete 5 because it took about 10 minutes for our server to take our order. Also, it took us about 35 minutes to find parking, but I guess that's expected on a Saturday night in Hayes Valley, so I don't really fault Domo for that.

We'll definitely be back for an intimate evening at Domo. There's a lot of charm and delicious food packed into a small space.

excerpts: Ordered a sweet potato roll and a dragon roll, which comes with shrimp tempura, cucumber, eel, and roe (hold the avo - unfortunately
, it doesn't agree with me).
The sweet potato was so yummy and topped with some kind of sauce.
I've never had eel before and the dragon roll was amazing.
sweet potato.author: Alyssa A.
sweet potato.review: Ate outside with a high school friend last night. Ordered a sweet potato roll and a dragon roll, which comes with shrimp tempura, cucumber, eel, and roe (hold the avo - unfortunately, it doesn't agree with me). The sweet potato was so yummy and topped with some kind of sauce. I've never had eel before and the dragon roll was amazing. We shared edamame which was properly cooked, and my friend had several pieces of nigiri and a temptation roll. Great service. Great green tea - it's the nutty kind, I can't remember what it's called.

excerpts:
Firecracker balls, Fiesta roll, Mango and black pepper

For the vegans: veggie croquettes, seaweed salad, sweet potato roll, shitake roll and the veggie roll.
sweet potato.author: Viola B.
sweet potato.review:
Best sushi, hands down.  Everyone I have taken here falls in love with this place. 

Very fresh, fast and friendly.  Prices are good too compared to other places.   The chefs are so fun to watch and there is one there that is so cute.  He talks to you while he is creating these little art pieces.  They play good music and it is just a fun experience. 

Why are they outstanding?  Firecracker balls, Fiesta roll, Mango and black pepper

For the vegans: veggie croquettes, seaweed salad, sweet potato roll, shitake roll and the veggie roll.  OMG the veggie roll is so good!   It has all the different flavors that come together in the roll, just like sushi should.  

You will leave very happy and be back very soon.

excerpts: I love their sweet potato roll.
The place is well designed, quaint, and has great music.
The staff is really nice and helpful.
Not sure I would go there with more than 1 other person because it's all bar seating except for 1 inside table and a couple outside.
But the bar makes for great people watching if face the window.
sweet potato.author: Michael H.
sweet potato.review: Some wonderfully delicious sushi. I love their sweet potato roll. The place is well designed, quaint, and has great music. The staff is really nice and helpful. Not sure I would go there with more than 1 other person because it's all bar seating except for 1 inside table and a couple outside. But the bar makes for great people watching if face the window.

excerpts: I got the Kobe Beef roll and the Alpha roll and the Old School Negihama roll!
All of them were delicious.
negihama.author: Sophia K.
negihama.review: Had a great experience going to this place! It is a small little restaurant but the wait was not bad. They do not take reservations. On a Saturday night around 730 our wait was only 15 minutes! I got the Kobe Beef roll and the Alpha roll and the Old School Negihama roll! All of them were delicious.

excerpts: The negihama was good.
negihama.author: Kris F.
negihama.review:
While there were two singles seated one away from the end, we were asked to move to not leave any spaces. I get why that's practical, but wonder why they didn't ask everyone. We were also the only Asians in the place. Maybe we look more compliant? Minus half star. 
The yellowtail sashimi had a nice texture, but had a persistent fishy taste. Minus one star, maybe a little more. It was fishy enough that I only had one piece. The two rolls (last two on the menu) we got were decent. The negihama was good.

excerpts: I would say the highlights of the meal were the negihama (y. tail, green onion, and sesame seeds) and karaage.
The negihama was buttery and delicious.
The karaage was crispy and tender.
Unfortunately, the spicy tuna roll was probably my least favorite.
The tuna lacked flavor, but was pretty spicy, and the roll had some sort of green sprouts in it.
negihama.author: Josh S.
negihama.review:
I've been on the hunt for my next solid sushi restaurant in the neighborhood, so I was excited to check out Domo.  The restaurant is located right in the heart of Hayes Valley and probably sits no more than 30-35 people at a time.  Specials are listed on their mirror, which is a pretty cool feature.  

My friend and I ordered a couple rolls, chicken karaage, and the hamachi kama.  Everything was presented quickly with little wait time.  The fish was served fresh and the hot dishes came out hot.  I would say the highlights of the meal were the negihama (y. tail, green onion, and sesame seeds) and karaage.  The negihama was buttery and delicious.  The karaage was crispy and tender.  Unfortunately, the spicy tuna roll was probably my least favorite.  The tuna lacked flavor, but was pretty spicy, and the roll had some sort of green sprouts in it.  The sprouts I think were there more for decoration, but really didn't do much for the roll itself (not like green onion would've).

Overall, the meal was just, ok.  I think Domo is a great spot to sit with a friend over a couple beers and order some apps, but I would skip on some of the other options.

excerpts: Seaweed salad was light and refreshing, salmon avocado lemon roll was ridiculously fresh and probably my favorite,
firecracker balls were deep fried FYI and not at all a "roll", and hamachi carpacchio was actually cooked (pretty sure this should be raw?) but still tasty.
salmon avocado lemon.author: Natalie H.
salmon avocado lemon.review:
Very small place - no tables, just bar seating. As in don't come here with a group of more than 2-3. Definitely would have walked past this place if we hadn't yelped sushi places in Hayes Valley. Waited a good 30mins last night, but it was worth it. I found my new favorite Japanese beer (!) - Orion - sweet, delicious, not just another Sapporo. Perfect with hot sake.

Reviews are right, they bring out your order as it's ready, so rolls actually came before our appetizers. Hmm. Seaweed salad was light and refreshing, salmon avocado lemon roll was ridiculously fresh and probably my favorite, firecracker balls were deep fried FYI and not at all a "roll", and hamachi carpacchio was actually cooked (pretty sure this should be raw?) but still tasty. Excellent presentation and lots of ginger, which I appreciate. 

Only negative is the VERY fishy smell of the restaurant. As in my clothes still smell today. Would probably go back if I was in the area and had some time to kill.

excerpts: We ordered the firecracker balls, the salmon avocado lemon roll, the domo roll, and the kobe beef roll.
Not entirely impressed with everything except the kobe beef roll.
It literally melts in your mouth.
salmon avocado lemon.author: Grace C.
salmon avocado lemon.review:
Cute little sushi spot right in Hayes Valley.  

Good sushi rolls.  Didn't have the sushi so can't comment on that.

We ordered the firecracker balls, the salmon avocado lemon roll, the domo roll, and the kobe beef roll.  Not entirely impressed with everything except the kobe beef roll.  It literally melts in your mouth.  The other stuff was good, but they kind of drench their rolls in too much sauce.

The service was very prompt.  I will visit again - but next time I'll order other stuff.

excerpts: The one roll i wasn't too crazy about was the salmon avocado lemon roll.
It sounds like a great idea for a roll but the lemon overpowered the salmon and avocado.
But all in all i really enjoyed my meal and i will definitely be coming back!
(and it doesn't hurt that it's in a cute neighborhood!)
salmon avocado lemon.author: Suzan L.
salmon avocado lemon.review: Do you ever go to a sushi restaurant and order the spicy tuna roll and it turns out to be really really spicy? Don't get me wrong, i LOVE spicy, but sometimes it just overpowers my palette and i can't taste anything. But you won't get that with the firecracker balls from domo! They were little balls of heaven! ugh just thinking about them makes my mouth water. The perfect amount of spice and fried crispiness and sauce...wow. Their jalapeno hamachi was mighty delicious as well, super fresh ingredients and you can taste the goodness. You might be thinking, jalapeno..is it spicy? NOPE! well, maybe just a tad but you mainly taste the fresh jalapeno taste without the tongue burning sensation cause the seeds don't come with it. The one roll i wasn't too crazy about was the salmon avocado lemon roll. It sounds like a great idea for a roll but the lemon overpowered the salmon and avocado. But all in all i really enjoyed my meal and i will definitely be coming back! (and it doesn't hurt that it's in a cute neighborhood!)

excerpts: The Jalepeno Hamachi is another good combo - I really like the bright flavor of the pepper mixed with the fish.
My vegetarian friend has good things to say about the veggie stuff.
We both like the edamame.
The service is brisk and efficient.
I prefer the female server we've gotten the past few times over the guy who served my friend and I tonight.
Can't wait to keep eating my way through the Domo menu!
jalepeno hamachi.author: Kat M.
jalepeno hamachi.review:
Where to begin....  My first time at Domo I wasn't terribly impressed, but it's been consistently awesome every time I went back.  I guess I figured out the right things to order.
Those things would be: The Fiesta Roll (not on the menu, currently written on the wall - get there before it goes away!)  Salsa and mango in sushi?  Absurdly good.
Crispy spicy tuna (also not on the menu): holy crap.  $9.60 of intense flavor and great textures!  Comes on an extra long plate, and the pieces of the roll barely fit into my mouth.  It's super filling and very indulgent.  
The nigiri is always very good and fresh tasting.  I've tried to be more adventurous in my fish consumption - the Tazmanian Trout is a new favorite.
The Spicy Hulk roll is fun and tasty.  Using cucumber as a wrapper is inventive and I wanted to lick the sauce off the plate.
The Rock and Roll is a good standard unagi roll.
The Jalepeno Hamachi is another good combo - I really like the bright flavor of the pepper mixed with the fish.
My vegetarian friend has good things to say about the veggie stuff.  We both like the edamame.  
The service is brisk and efficient.  I prefer the female server we've gotten the past few times over the guy who served my friend and I tonight.  
Can't wait to keep eating my way through the Domo menu!

excerpts: The Fire Cracker Balls had a good combination of crunchy, creamy & spicy.
fire cracker balls.author: Rose A.
fire cracker balls.review:
4.5 Stars

Don't expect to come here with a large group.  Due to its size, I would say this is more of a place to spend some QT with a loved one or catch up with a friend.

The food is pretty gosh darn delicious.  I was a bit disappointed that they did not have the uni crudo but the scallop & salmon crudo pretty much made up for it.  The Fire Cracker Balls had a good combination of crunchy, creamy & spicy. I loved the Spicy Hulk, which is spicy tuna wrapped in cucumber instead of rice.

I would definitely go back.  Especially to try that uni crudo...

excerpts: We ended up getting the "Fire Cracker Balls" roll and let me tell you - unbelievable!
I had no clue what I was looking at
and once I took the brave step of putting it in my mouth for consumption I was thrilled beyond belief.
There could not have been enough of these on the plate or in my stomach.
The Spider roll and Negi-Hama roll were both pleasant and not too huge.
Spider roll ends are a bit tough to swallow on one bite but this sushi was made well and didn't fall apart after numerous bites.
fire cracker balls.author: Kevin J.
fire cracker balls.review:
Domo is that special place that could easily be missed or mistaken after 4 steps of passing by.  The sign is brightly lit but small in size keeping this place a secret little gem in Hayes Valley.  The prices are very reasonable and the food it outstandingly delicious. 

The seating is a bit sparse and the wait can get a tad long but it's well worth the wait.  Surprisingly the ambiance was subdued but it was nice.  Notorius B.I.G. was playing in the background while every diner kept there conversations on a light note.  It was shockingly at the appropriate noise level for such a small place and so many people.

I shared the Edamame ($4), Miso Soup ($3/each), and Seaweed Salad ($5) to start.  Followed up with a nice unfiltered Sake to wash down the meal.  The bottle was only $10 and gave us plenty of fluid to stay at that perfect level of intoxication.  Well, for me at least.  We ended up getting the "Fire Cracker Balls" roll and let me tell you - unbelievable!  I had no clue what I was looking at and once I took the brave step of putting it in my mouth for consumption I was thrilled beyond belief.  There could not have been enough of these on the plate or in my stomach.  The Spider roll and Negi-Hama roll were both pleasant and not too huge.  Spider roll ends are a bit tough to swallow on one bite but this sushi was made well and didn't fall apart after numerous bites.  The rice was used appropriately without overpowering the fish and ingredients inside.

I was superbly happy with our dining choice for sushi and will be going back most definitely.

excerpts: Also try the spicy tuna crudo (get 2 orders), hamachi carpaccio, and fire cracker balls.
fire cracker balls.author: Av A.
fire cracker balls.review:
I'm rating this 5 stars because I've gone enough times to know the wait is worth it. 

It's a TINY place so it's not good for groups and esp for dinner there will be a wait -- write your name + number, walk to Suppenkuche and grab a drink until the hostess calls when your table is ready, typical wait time is 45-1hr. It has a rustic intimate vibe so it's a great spot for dates, the plus side is they're almost always on point with the music; think Toro Y Moi, Portishead, Modjo, etc.

We've tried almost everything on the menu, the price range is expected for the area. They have specials written on the mirror, look for it and try at least one nigiri or appetizer. Also try the spicy tuna crudo (get 2 orders), hamachi carpaccio, and fire cracker balls.

excerpts: Fire Cracker Balls--
These came out very small.
fire cracker balls.author: Jessica T.
fire cracker balls.review:
Domo is something different than what I normally eat.  My friends and I chose this place because another sushi place was too packed so I didn't read the full details before coming here.  The place was really small and cute.  My friends and I were the first group there for dinner.

We ordered the following:

Hawaiian Style Tuna Poke--pretty good but nothing too special.  They just mixed tuna and wakame and topped it with tako.

Crudos--Salmon & Scallops.  They were both delicious. It's probably my favorite dish ordered.  They are in spoons and it's like drinking a shooter.

Sake Nigiri--nothing too special. It was a lot smaller than I expected but still good.

Rock & Roll--unagi and avocado roll.  The ratio of avocado to unagi was 2:1. I like avocado though so thought the roll was good.

Fire Cracker Balls--These came out very small.  It just tasted like deep fried rice balls topped with their sauces.

Spicy Hulk--tuna inside a cucumber wrap. Good but probably wouldn't order it again.

The owner was very nice to us and constantly checked up on us.  This place can be pricey if you're looking to leave full.  I had to order more food because I was not full and no where near satisfied.

I would recommend this place as a place to try at least once.

excerpts: Fire Cracker Balls
* - Loved this.
fire cracker balls.author: Kristin C.
fire cracker balls.review:
Cute and cozy sushi place in Hayes Valley.  My sister and I were so happy we stumbled upon Domo right before it became crowded for dinner.  We grabbed a seat at the sushi bar and were able to place our order directly through the sushi chefs. Service was prompt and our food came out quickly. We tried the following three dishes:

1. *Fried Baby Octopus* (chalkboard special) - this was amazing, probably my favorite dish out of the three. Succulent baby octopus fried to a perfect crisp with some spicy mayo and micro screens scattered on the plate, what more could you ask for in an appetizer? 

2. *Fire Cracker Balls* - Loved this. A perfect blend of spicy tuna, crispiness, tobiko, sriracha, and spicy mayo. 

3. *Castro Roll* - It's nice to find a place that uses 'real' crab instead of 'imitation' crab in their rolls.  This was decent but definitely over-shadowed by our appetizers. I would probably go for something else on the menu next time. 

All-in-all a tasty meal--we plan on returning soon to try the crudos, toro, and other chalkboard specials!  Street parking is available but you will need search for it and may have to walk a few blocks. There is indoor and outdoor seating (very limited!).

excerpts: This was followed by the Fire Cracker Balls (6 small balls) that everyone around us had also ordered.
fire cracker balls.author: Jennifer L.
fire cracker balls.review:
I took a friend here for her birthday, so we ordered a little bit of everything that other yelpers had recommended.  

We started with the Salmon Crudo which was SO good + had a lot of flavor for how small the portion was (it was served in spoons).  But at $6 for two, the crudo was a little steep.  

This was followed by the Fire Cracker Balls (6 small balls) that everyone around us had also ordered.  For $10, it was also steep, especially if you're actually trying to satiate your hunger.

The Hulk Roll came in 5 pieces and tasted like "healthy" sushi because of the cucumber sheet.   It doesn't look that flavorful, but it is!

We finished off with the Domo Roll, which tasted like your typical American-y saucy sushi roll... so I loved it.

Overall, Domo = the best fusion Japanese food I've ever had.  The seating isn't ideal for a date night, but the food is.  Small portions, lots of things to try / share that look cool, and you won't stuff your face in front of whoever you're trying to impress!

Oh we also ordered the sake... not sure which one, but it was so good!!  Sippable.

excerpts: We had the Castro rolls and the fire cracker balls.
It was delicious.
Highly recommended
fire cracker balls.author: Carol R.
fire cracker balls.review: We had the Castro rolls and the fire cracker balls. It was delicious. Highly recommended

excerpts: Fire cracker balls lived up to their name!
fire cracker balls.author: Kathryn C.
fire cracker balls.review:
Surprising and creative combinations with super fresh fish!

Fire cracker balls lived up to their name!
Domo roll was over the top and deliciously so
Dragon roll was well executed
Fish tacos was a super fresh interpretation, with a seaweed "shell"

excerpts: Highly recommend fire cracker balls.
fire cracker balls.author: Shawn T.
fire cracker balls.review: My go to local sushi place. I went with my roommate one weekday night around 6pm and it was only us and another duo there. By the time we left it was almost full, but I've seen the place get packed, especially weekend nights. Highly recommend fire cracker balls.

excerpts: We ordered the Spicy Tuna Roll, Jalapeno Hamachi, Fire Cracker Balls, and miso soup.
Fire Cracker Balls:
So TASTY!
You should definitely get these.
fire cracker balls.author: Maliha Z.
fire cracker balls.review:
I went to an early dinner at Domo on a Wednesday night and it was great for a quiet dinner on a weeknight after work. The area is really cute, lots of bars and restaurants. 

Ambiance: Casual, relaxed. Small restaurant with bar style seating, a few small tables inside, and 3 round tables outside. 

Food: Fresh and delicious. We ordered the Spicy Tuna Roll, Jalapeno Hamachi, Fire Cracker Balls, and miso soup. 

Spicy Tuna Roll: Really good and actually spicy. The fish was very fresh and seasoned well. 

Jalapeno Hamachi: I wish the Sea Salt and Jalapeno had more flavor. I really wanted to like this roll but I don't think it had the kick I was looking for. 

Fire Cracker Balls: So TASTY! You should definitely get these. They are crispy on the outside with spicy mayo and unagi sauce on top. 


All in all, the menu is creative and food fresh so I definitely want to go back and try some of their other items.

excerpts: We also had the Fire Cracker Balls which are absolutely not to be missed.
They are a refreshing take on the overplayed fried maki motif.
We also snagged some negi toro (also from the specials menu)
maki which was fatty and delicious.
fire cracker balls.author: Adam R.
fire cracker balls.review:
Came in with my girlfriend on a Monday night at the end of a long weekend. Domo is tiny - it seats maybe 20 people - and it was full when we arrived. We put our names on the list and settled in for a wait. The sushi gods were smiling on us because a few minutes later, the entire restaurant paid their checks simultaneously and left. We sat at the outward-facing counter with a lovely view of the cute block Domo inhabits.

We started with edamame. It was lightly dusted with salt: perfect. We had snow crab (from the specials menu) and unagi nigiri, both of which were fresh and flavorful. We continued with the Alpha roll which adds mango to the usual combination of fish and accoutrements for a fun twist. We also had the Fire Cracker Balls which are absolutely not to be missed. They are a refreshing take on the overplayed fried maki motif. We also snagged some negi toro (also from the specials menu) maki which was fatty and delicious. The only food I didn't love was the fish tacos - too many flavors and textures competing with each other.

The service was attentive but there was a serious lull between our first round of food and the rest of it. Would have been nice to have our food a little more evenly spaced out. Obviously though that's a nit pick because I had to find something to criticize.

Can't wait to make it back. Definitely my new go-to sushi in SF.

excerpts: Fire Cracker Balls - Yelp tips told us to get it.
The Fire Cracker Balls were indeed crackin'.
fire cracker balls.author: Emmeline A.
fire cracker balls.review:
I'm truly a sucker for good music playing in the background, and Domo definitely gets it right.  There's something about the mix of jazz and sushi, and of R&B/hip-hip and sushi that really works. Domo to me is the less pretentious, more casual brother to Yoshi's, without live music, and in a cozier home.

Aside from the ambience, the staff was very friendly and helpful.  The folks delivering our food placed the plates on our table with little jokes and spritely remarks. 

The food itself was delectable.  While pricey, I'd say the food is well worth it. 

Here's the run-down of what we divulged in:
Hawaiian Style Tuna Poke - delicious, nice flavors, but not groundbreaking in terms of innovative flavors, yet still worth the price.
Small crudos, spicy tuna and scallop - once again delicious: tuna tasted fresh, seasoning was good, but I particularly enjoyed the scallop.
Fire Cracker Balls - Yelp tips told us to get it. The Fire Cracker Balls were indeed crackin'.
Domo Roll - I'm not a fan of the Lion King roll to begin with, but this roll changed my mind for the night.
Kobe Beef - as an unusual item, we obviously had to try this. Verdict: The beef was well seasoned, and the roll itself was rich and creamy (because of the avocado). Overall, I'd re-order, yes.
Mac Daddy - daddy got it right. delicious.

Thanks for the meal, Domo.

excerpts: Fire Cracker Balls.
I mean, with a name like that how could you go wrong?
Crunchy, spicy bits of goodness that burst in your mouth (thanks to the roe on top).
It's, quite literally, a flavor explosion-osion-osion-osion (echo fade)!
Spicy tuna rolled up, breaded and deep fried topped with a variety of sauces, scallions and roe.
So spicy.
So good.
I almost regret getting them because I know I'll end up craving them and will be unsatisfied as they are only available across the country.
fire cracker balls.author: Annette J.
fire cracker balls.review:
Fire Cracker Balls. I mean, with a name like that how could you go wrong? Crunchy, spicy bits of goodness that burst in your mouth (thanks to the roe on top). It's, quite literally, a flavor explosion-osion-osion-osion (echo fade)! Spicy tuna rolled up, breaded and deep fried topped with a variety of sauces, scallions and roe. So spicy. So good. I almost regret getting them because I know I'll end up craving them and will be unsatisfied as they are only available across the country. Sad face.

Domo is a teeny tiny little sushi joint not far from my magical wonderland Miette. I stumbled upon it while wandering around and, after a week long binge on super rich foods, I decided sushi might make a good, light dinner. Of course I order the deep fried roll but that's neither here nor there. The point is, this place was good. 

It's got mega limited eating. I was exploring solo so I was able to grab a seat at the bar quickly as there was one lone chair available. The wait wasn't huge but there were a handful of folks milling about at the door waiting for spots to open up. 

I was having a severe case of my eyes are bigger than my stomach. Everything on the menu looked so good. I wanted to try 2 appetizers and a crap ton of rolls but I limited myself to some edemame (decent--I'm not sure how edemame can be kind of subpar but this one was. There was just something a bit different to me in terms of the flavor) and a couple of rolls--the firecracker balls and the domo roll. Still too much but oh so good.

The firecracker balls were my favorite, as I mentioned, but the domo roll was a close second. A california roll wrapped in cooked salmon and seared scallops topped with spicy mayo and a few other sauces. Oh good lord those scallops were good. I wish there had been more of them (it was more salmon heavy). Although delicious it was difficult to eat. I think the scallops made it a bit hard to roll so the pieces fell apart. Huge sushi pet peeve of mine but it was damn tasty I let it slide. SLIDE RIGHT INTO MY BELLY, THAT IS.

The service is quick but not overly friendly. The sushi chefs were right in front of me but barely glanced in our direction. Focus! There were only a couple of waitstaff around and I saw them doing things like preparing the edemame and other small apps. They do a lot more than just taking your order and bringing your plates! The kitchen is visible and super teeny tiny. Like, studio kitchen small. It's amazing that they churn out so many delicious hot dishes (like the FCB) with a space as small as that. Impressive!

The prices for the special rolls are a little up there but worth it if you like sushi. Ugh, writing this review had be reliving the experience in my brain and now I'm all sad face because I'm missing those scallops and hot little nuggets. Boohoohoo. Damn you Domo for being so darn good.

excerpts: Moving on, I ordered some of the sushi rolls including the Fire Cracker Balls, Sexy Mama, and the Domo Roll.
Each were fantastic with Sexy Mama being my favorite!
The Sexy Mama is really great if you love the taste of citrus in every bite because it's completely lined with thinly sliced lemons.
fire cracker balls.author: Ann S.
fire cracker balls.review:
Domo is a great place for some good Japanese food. 

I started off with the edamame, miso soup, and seaweed salad appetizers followed by spoonfuls of small crudos. The salmon crudo was fresh and perfect with the small wedge of avocado. The spicy tuna crudo had a nice kick to it with the addition of the sriracha hot sauce. The scallop crudo was wonderfully balanced with delicious seasoning. Last but not least, the uni was delicate, bright, and very fresh. Really, how else would you prefer sea urchin gonads for consumption? Mmm... That's some serious good eats!

Moving on, I ordered some of the sushi rolls including the Fire Cracker Balls, Sexy Mama, and the Domo Roll. Each were fantastic with Sexy Mama being my favorite! The Sexy Mama is really great if you love the taste of citrus in every bite because it's completely lined with thinly sliced lemons. Yum!

Domo is located in Hayes Valley in a cool neighborhood, perfect for outdoor seating. 

Service was attentive and friendly!

excerpts: Fire Cracker Balls:
Good, but I've had other fried sushi before and this was about on par.
fire cracker balls.author: Raina D.
fire cracker balls.review:
This was some of the best sushi I've had in a very long time!! Although, I have to admit that I enjoy more adventurous plates rather than traditional rolled sushi, so this is an adequate review if that is what you're looking for.  We ordered six plates to split and tried a bit of most of them:
